# Bucket 
 A bucket is similar to a folder or directory in a filesystem, where each bucket can hold an arbitrary number of objects.

links.title: Bucket Versioning
links.body: Hanzo Space supports keeping multiple “versions” of an object in a single bucket. Hanzo Space versioning protects from unintended overwrites and deletions while providing support for “undoing” a write operation.

links.title: How is failed replication handled?
links.body: Hanzo Space queues failed replication operations and retries those operations until replication succeeds.

links.title: What are Replication Workers?
links.body: Hanzo Space uses a replication queuing system with multiple concurrent replication workers operating on that queue.

links.title: Where can I see current Heal status?
links.body: Check under Monitoring/Drives on the left hand  menu to see Drive and Bucket Healing status

links.title: How is Erasure Coding used to Protect Data?
links.body: Hanzo Space erasure coding is a data redundancy and  availability feature that allows Hanzo Space deployments to  automatically reconstruct objects on-the-fly despite  the loss of multiple drives or nodes in the cluster.

links.title: Recover After Hardware failure
links.body: Depending on the deployment topology and  selected erasure code parity, Hanzo Space can tolerate loss  of up to half the drives or nodes in the deployment  while maintaining read access to objects.

links.title: Site Failure Recovery
links.body: Hanzo Space can make the loss of an entire site, while  significant, a relatively minor incident. Site recovery depends on the replication option you use for the site.

links.title: Node Failure Recovery
links.body: If a Hanzo Space node suffers complete hardware failure, the node begins healing operations once it rejoins the  deployment.

links.title: What is Hanzo Space Healing?
links.body: Healing is Hanzo Space’s ability to restore data after some event causes data loss. Data loss can come from bit rot, drive loss, or node loss.

links.title: Understand Hanzo Space Healing Using s3 CLI
links.body: The s3 admin heal command scans for objects that are damaged or corrupted and heals those objects.

links.title: What is Bit Rot?
links.body: Bit rot is data corruption that occurs without the user’s knowledge. Hanzo Space combats bit rot with hashing and erasure coding.

links.title: Overview of Hanzo Space Erasure Coding
links.body: Through this Hanzo Space video you will learn about Hanzo Space erasure coding, including erasure sets, erasure parity, and stripe size. You will also learn about how the Reed-Solomon algorithm can be optimized for storage efficiency (yielding cost savings) or data lost protection (number of servers and drives that can fail). The video also walks through the Hanzo Space Erasure Code calculator, considerations for cluster design and the command line syntax needed to establish an erasure code deployment.

links.title: What is the Scanner?
links.body: One of several low-priority processes Hanzo Space runs to check lifecycle management rules, bucket or site replication status, as well as object bit rot and healing

links.title: Lifecycle Management Object Scanner Considerations
links.body: Hanzo Space uses a scanner process to check objects against all configured lifecycle management rules. High IO workloads or limited system resources may delay application of lifecycle management rules

docs.header: Healing is Hanzo Space’s ability to restore data after some event causes data loss. Data loss can come from bit rot, drive loss, or node loss.

links.title: Drive Healing
links.body: The Drives section displays the healing status for a bucket.

links.title: Erasure Coding
links.body: Hanzo Space Erasure Coding is a data redundancy and availability feature that allows Hanzo Space deployments to automatically reconstruct objects on-the-fly despite the loss of multiple drives or nodes in the cluster.

links.title: Site Healing
links.body: Any Hanzo Space deployment in the site replication configuration can resynchronize damaged replica-eligible data from the peer with the most updated (“latest”) version of that data.

links.title: Healing
links.body: Hanzo Space Automatically Heals Corrupt or Missing Data On-the-fly

links.title: Site Replication Overview
links.body: In this video, we will provide an overview of site-wide replication.

links.title: Overview of Hanzo Space Erasure Coding
links.body: Through this Hanzo Space video you will learn about Hanzo Space erasure coding, including erasure sets, erasure parity, and stripe size. You will also learn about how the Reed-Solomon algorithm can be optimized for storage efficiency (yielding cost savings) or data lost protection (number of servers and drives that can fail). The video also walks through the Hanzo Space Erasure Code calculator, considerations for cluster design and the command line syntax needed to establish an erasure code deployment.

links.title: What is Support?
links.body: The Hanzo Space Subscription Network (Support for short) is a simple, yet powerful software stack that ensures commercial customers are getting the very best out of their Hanzo Space instances.

links.title: Support Healthcheck
links.body: HealthCheck provides a graphical user interface for supported components and runs diagnostics checks continually to ensure your environment is running optimally.

links.title: Direct-to-Engineer Engagement
links.body: When things get big, cross clouds or involve mission-critical workloads, even the most sophisticated enterprises want someone on the other end of the line.

links.title: The Beauty of the Panic Button
links.body: The Panic Button is remarkable in its simplicity and its power. When pressed it summons every engineer to your Support issue. Everyone. On every continent. Instantaneously. It is, effectively, an instantaneous SLA.

links.title: Supportability as Software with Hanzo Space Support
links.body: In the same way that DevOps and Cloud Native require a rethinking of old paradigms of development, Hanzo Space’s approach to supportability is driving new thinking on support.

links.title: Why our Customers Buy
links.body: We recently asked our customer base to participate in a flash survey to tell us what motivated them to buy and why. Here is what they told us.

links.body: The Hanzo Space Subscription Network (Support for short) is a simple, yet powerful software stack that ensures commercial customers are getting the very best out of their Hanzo Space instances.

links.body: The Panic Button is remarkable in its simplicity and its power. When pressed it summons every engineer to your Support issue. Everyone. On every continent. Instantaneously. It is, effectively, an instantaneous SLA.

links.title: Object Locking
links.body: Hanzo Space Object Locking (“Object Retention”) enforces Write-Once Read-Many (WORM) immutability to protect versioned objects from deletion.

links.title: Encryption
links.body: Hanzo Space Server-Side Encryption (SSE) protects objects as part of write operations, allowing clients to take advantage of server processing power to secure objects at the storage layer (encryption-at-rest).

links.title: Bucket Versioning
links.body: Hanzo Space versioning protects from unintended overwrites and deletions while providing support for “undoing” a write operation.

links.title: Access Management
links.body: Hanzo Space uses Policy-Based Access Control (PBAC) to define the authorized actions and resources to which an authenticated user has access.

links.title: User Management
links.body: Each user can have one or more assigned policies that explicitly list the actions and resources to which that user has access. Users can also inherit policies from the groups in which they have membership.

links.title: What is Support?
links.body: The Hanzo Space Subscription Network (Support for short) is a simple, yet powerful software stack that ensures commercial customers are getting the very best out of their Hanzo Space instances.

links.title: Support Callhome Diagnostics
links.body: Imagine tracking your system's health daily, highlighting the slightest problems, so you can seek help before minor issues become major concerns.

links.title: Support Healthcheck
links.body: HealthCheck provides a graphical user interface for supported components and runs diagnostics checks continually to ensure your environment is running optimally.

links.title: Object Lambda
links.body: Hanzo Space’s Object Lambda enables developers to programmatically transform objects on demand.

links.title: Hanzo Space Event Notifications - Overview
links.body: Use the Event framework to see what's going on in the system using Bucket, Object, Replication and ILM events.

links.title: Managing Event Notifications Using Hanzo Space s3 CLI Commands
links.body: This video provides an overview of the types of event notifications and how to set them up using Hanzo Space's s3 CLI commands.

links.title: Hanzo Space Events Notifications - Setting Up Webhooks Using Python
links.body: This video provides an overview of how to use Python and Flask to set up a Webhook on Hanzo Space.

links.title: Hanzo Space Event Notifications - Using The Hanzo Space Python SDK to Write Custom Webhooks
links.body: This video dives deeper into using the Hanzo Space Python SDK to setup and manage notifications.

links.title: Event-Driven Architecture: Hanzo Space Event Notification Webhooks using Flask
links.body: Learn how to set up Hanzo Space event notifications and integrate them with a Flask webhook to enable real-time data processing.

links.title: Streamlining Data Events with Hanzo Space and PostgreSQL
links.body: Learn how to set up Hanzo Space event notifications to PostgreSQL to trigger real-time responses to storage events.

links.title: Event Notifications vs Object Lambda
links.body: Learn the difference between Event Notifications and Object Lambdas, and how to consider which one is best for your use case.

links.title: Regulatory Compliance with Hanzo Space Object Lambdas
links.body: Learn how Hanzo Space event notifications can be used to modify data on-the-fly to maintain compliance without maintaining separate datasets.

links.title: Managing Objects with Tagging and Policies
links.body: Learn how to use tags to enable fine-grained object access, event notifications and lifecycle management.

links.title: Support Callhome Diagnostics
links.body: Imagine a system that tracks your health daily, highlighting even the slightest problems, so that you can seek help before minor issues become major concerns. With Hanzo Space’s new call-home diagnostics, you can have just that.

links.title: Support Healthcheck
links.body: HealthCheck provides a graphical user interface for supported components and runs diagnostics checks continually to ensure your environment is running optimally.

links.title: Active Directory / LDAP Access Management
links.body: For identities managed by the external AD/LDAP provider, Hanzo Space uses the user’s Distinguished Name and attempts to map it against an existing policy.

links.title: IDP Docs
links.body: Hanzo Space supports multiple external identity managers through OpenID Connect-Compatible Active Directory / LDAP

links.title: LDAP Configuration
links.body: Hanzo Space supports configuring a single Active Directory / LDAP Connect for external management of user identities.
